, that’s seventy-thousand dollars not financing your retirement.
It might even contribute to you not being able to retire when you want. Forcing you to continue to go to work.

And let’s not forget about all the things $70K can get you (other than a nice car). That’s more than enough to probably visit all the places left on your bucket list, give your kids a decent learning experience, or pay the ten-year rent on a modest condo.
I mean, if you have the money, it’s a no-brainer.
But bankrupting a better future on a faster sleeker drive is a waste.
